thread.title: Meet the astronauts at Novato Space Festival
thread.title_full: Meet the astronauts at Novato Space Festival

author: By Christine Delsol
title: Meet the astronauts at Novato Space Festival
text:
Meet the astronauts at Novato Space Festival Christine Delso , San Francisco Chronicle By Christine Delsol Published 1:09 am, Thursday, July 16, 2015 Astronaut Dan Bursch with young visitors at the Novato Space Festival in 2014. Photo: Space Station Museum Astronaut Dan Bursch with young visitors at the Novato Space... 
Teen survived plane crash, leaves hospital; wreckage found Page 1 of 1 
You don’t have to go to Houston or Cape Canaveral to rub elbows with astronauts or inspect a lunar module and a moon buggy. Visitors can do that and more during the Novato Space Festival, sponsored by the city’s Space Station Museum . Apollo 15 astronaut Al Worden and space shuttle astronauts Jerry Ross , Yvonne Cagle , Rhea Seddon , Hoot Gibson and Don Bursch will be on hand to answer questions. Bursch and several other astronauts serve on the board of advisers for the museum, which boasts one of the largest collections of space artifacts, such as a Soviet-era cosmonaut flight suit, International Space Station equipment, a space shuttle hatch, photos and models. (The lunar module and moon buggy are replicas.) 
Vitals: Aug. 1, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Free. Pacheco Plaza, 464 Ignacio Blvd., Novato. (415) 506-3070. www.thespacestationca.org. 
Street life in Morro Bay: Morro Bay takes it to the streets when its modest Old Town fills with more than 100 booths with vendors offering arts, crafts, gifts, home and garden accessories, and other hand-crafted items. Though the emphasis is on merchandise, there’s also plenty of food, live entertainment and leisurely walks along Morro Bay Boulevard, just a few blocks from the ocean and views of that iconic rock. Aug. 2, 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Free. (877) 478-9477. www.morro-bay.net/mbma. 
Feeling Japanese in L.A.: The Nisei Week Japanese Festival, celebrating its 75th year in Los Angeles’ Little Tokyo, is actually two weekend festivals. The big event is the Grand Parade, on the first Sunday, but that weekend also has taiko drumming, martial arts, bonsai, calligraphy and flower-arranging demonstrations. The World Byoza (pot-sticker) Eating Championship and Ondo street dancing are main features of the second weekend. Aug. 15-23; see website for schedule. Free admission; charge for some activities. (213) 687-7193. www.jaccc.org.
